Story: It was almost closing time at the store, and I was counting the register when my phone buzzed with a frantic call from my best friend. She was stranded on the highway, her voice shaky as she begged me to come get her right away. My heart raced—I knew she’d do the same for me, and I couldn’t stand the thought of her alone in the dark. But as I glanced down, I noticed a small discrepancy in the register. Store policy was clear: any irregularity, no matter how minor, had to be reported and resolved before leaving. My manager had drilled it into us—no exceptions. I felt torn in two. My friend needed me, and I wanted to drop everything and run to her side. But I also knew the responsibility I carried as a cashier, the trust placed in me to follow the rules. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other. My hands trembled as I stared at the register, my phone still buzzing in my pocket, caught between loyalty and duty.
